name: Catfish au Lait
headline: Catfish au Lait
recipeIngredient: 1 teaspoon crab boil seasoning (recommended: Old Bay)

recipeInstructions.text: Combine the milk, crab boil seasoning, pepper, salt, and onion in an electric skillet, cover, and bring to a simmer. Add the catfish to the liquid, spooning some of the liquid over the fillets.
Reduce the heat to low, around 140 to 145 degrees, cover the skillet, and poach for 6 to 9 minutes.

review.reviewBody: My wife has been making this for years, and it is always a hit. Fix this for your friends that think catfish is only good fried.
Great recipe. I did sauté the onion in a little butter first till translucent. I don't have an electric skillet - just used the stove top.

Being from Mississippi (the catfish capital of the world I have cooked catfish as many ways as Bubba Gump has cooked shrimp. This recipe is beyond delicious! My only regret is there wasn't company here to enjoy this FAB meal along with my hubs and I! I promise you - next time, there will be guests who I already know will be bragging on what a great cook I am! Laugh! Thanks Alton for another recipe to add to my expanding recipe box!

Very good. I goofed and used catfish nuggets instead of fillets and don't recommend anybody try that one, but we'll have this again with the correct cut of fish. My electric skillet was just too hot to do this correctly so next time it'll be in a pan on the stove. So simple and yet so tasty!

the taste of this recipe will make you feel like your floating in the air. its delicious! My husband hates fish or anything slimy. Well, i just cooked this the other night for dinner, i added uncle Ben's sweat rice and some carrots and my husband loved it and my kids did too.

My spouse is not a fish eater and when I said the word "catfish", I knew I was in trouble. I don't ever remember eating catfish, so this was to be an adventure ... and off the the market I went.

It was incredible though it did take longer to cook than the application called for. And my spouse, who was mentally prepared to hate it, ate an entire fillet. I was granted permission to make it again ... even for company! Our side dish was asparagus which went perfectly with the fish.

'Blackened' is still our favorite, but this sounded too wierd to not try!  Glad we did!  Based on several 'sauce too thin' reviews:  after fish was removed from pan, I mixed 1T flour with 1T melted butter, then wisked that into sauce unitl thickened.  VERY nice consistency!  Would maybe cut back the Old Bay just a tad.
This is one of my favorite fish dishes with out a crispy fried coating.
Tasty and very simple to make. Word of warning - wash your pots and dishes soon after cooking. I left mine out a while and once that evaporated milk dries it is very difficult to get off.
and it worked fabulously!  Bluefish is a little tough to match to a recipe but it worked like a charm in this instance.
The fish was firm and moist, and the sauce was delicious.  My only complaint is that the sauce is very thin.  Next time, I think I'll thicken up the sauce a little with maybe a cornstarch slurry.

My husband and I moved from southern Louisiana to northern Georgia and I must say we have had a very hard time recreating authentic Louisiana food.It just didn't taste right every time.But after trying tis recipe, we both felt as if we were back home,well, minus the humidity of course.Thank you Alton for bringing back those good ol' Louisiana memories!

This catfish was awesome!  I was kinda iffy about trying a milky fish dish but when my hubby was making this, the aroma was fabulous and I just had to taste it.  This is now my favorite fish recipe.  Thanks Altonator!
I followed Altons directions and at the end I took the fish out and put in one can of cream of shrimp and raised the temperature to thicken as a sauce and poured it over the fish and rice... YUM !

I was really excited to try this recipe, as I love Old Bay and both my husband and I love catfish.  What a disappointment.  First off, it did not cook in the time specified, more like 15 minutes.  Even then, the fish was mushy rather than firm and tender.  The sauce, although it was very thin, tasted fantastic, but the fish itself did not seem to take on any of the flavor of the poaching liquid.  We wound up dousing the fish in hot sauce just to be able to eat it.  After this, I will stick to coated and fried or at least sauteed.
I liked the fish very much.  It was tender and flaky with the right amount of flavor.  I will use this recipe again!

I was skeptical about the milk and my mother was skeptical of the catfish normal "fishy" taste. It was REALLLY good.  It was easy and fast and it was sooooo good, we didn't have enough. We all wanted more and before we knew it, it was gone!

I was very impressed with this meal. I just used a non-stick pan over an open flame on my stove and it turned out great. Sauce was consistency of water, which is okay since it didn't affect flavor, but I would prefer sauce a tad thicker; maybe letting it set longer would fix this, I don't know.

Served with sourdough bread and a baked potato it was as good a meal as I could get in local fish restaurants, but far cheaper at home. Total cost was about $7 for the meal. Tasted even better warmed up the next day.
You have to try it. By far the easiest way to cook catfish. Tastes awesome.

This is an excellent recipe especially if you are crunched for time.  It doesn't overwhelm the meat either which I like; it left the fish (we used halibut)light and flavorful.  Nice recipe to switch it up a bit instead of baked, fried or grilled fish all the time.

This recipe was so simple, but can be presented so elegantly, and the taste was absolutely splendiferous!!! Thank you for a new twist on my favorite kind of fish. I live in Wisconsin, and Catfish rules!!!

Thanks again for the great recipe, Alton, you have some very cool ideas, recipes, and information. Kudo's, keep it up!

When shopping for ingredients, the store was out of the Old Bay seasoning. I bought the Zatarain's crab boil instead and it was good. The whole spices looked really nice served on the fish. I had some really big, thick filets so I spooned the liquid over frequently, flipped them a couple times, and covered the pan for awhile and they turned out perfect. I'll probably use a purple onion and a bit more salt and pepper next time.
Poaching is not really my thing, but there was tons of flavor in this. A nice alternative to my usualy fried catfish
This is a good easy weekday meal that is simple and quick.  Gotta love A.B.!
Very good, will make again!
Really good receipt, I'm in Australia and catfish is NOT easily found...but any freshwater mild flavored fish works really nicely.

Really delicious and really easy. The fillets I used were a little large ... so I flipped at 5 minutes and cooked a little longer. I was surprised at how much sauce there was -- didn't seem to be much in the skillet. But over the fish and over rice and still plenty left over.

I used cod on this recipe, and it turned out very good. My electric skillet has a wider area than Alton's, and I was worried I didn't have enough liquid. It was definitely shallow-poached (like The Frenchman'
s fish in the show), but it still came out great. Just make sure you have flat pieces of meat. I also turned my fish halfway through cooking.

My skillet also doesn't have temp markings below 200 (just a SIMMER setting), so I had to test it with water first and mark where it was about 140 on my dial. Then I used my probe thermometer to monitor the temp during poaching. The recipe says 6-9 minutes, but Alton says you can leave it there for hours, so I left it for 20 minutes to make sure it was done (and my side dishes weren't done yet). It was delicious. Very moist and tender with a good sauce. My wife wa turned off by the looks of the poaching liquid, but she tried it, and she loved it!

Great recipe and super-easy, even if I had to do a little work to get my skillet to the right temp. I love that you can cook the fish and just let it sit as long as it takes to get the rest of dinner ready.
I've used this recipe for all types of fish.

When I saw this recipe on the show, I knew I had to try it.  I'm always looking for alternatives to fried catfish.  This recipe is great.  I'm not sure if it's the milk that does it, but the entire filet is infused with the spices.  And the texture is wonderful!  I'll serve this to my next group of unsuspecting guests!
Great recipe but light on the Old Bay.
They were okay.
This recipe is amazingly simple and great for doing ahead of time since it can simmer for so long with no problem.  It got raves when we made it for company.
easy and very tasty
My kids ages 5 1/2 and 4 1/2 love this, too.  A recipe doesn't get much easier than this.  The first time I made it, the sauce seemed very spicy and salty, but the fish was perfect.
This fish is so good, even the picky eater of my family loved it!  Another great recipe from Alton Brown.  Thanks!
My husband and 3 year old daughter love this recipe.  We use halibut instead of catfish.  We've also used salmon filets, and they were good too...or so I'm told by the family.  :)
Loved this recipe. Didn't have an electric frying pan, but managed to do it on the stove over a very low flame. Sauce comes out soupy, but good over rice!
